**Conclusion**  
For i.i.d. observations drawn from a normal distribution truncated to the interval  
\((a,b)=(\mu-\lambda\sigma,\;\mu+\lambda\sigma)\) with unknown \((\mu,\sigma^{2},\lambda)\), the usual regularity conditions for MLE asymptotics fail because the support of the density depends on the parameters.  
Re‑parameterising the model by the three‑vector  

\[
\phi=(\mu,\sigma,\lambda)^{\!\top},
\qquad 
W_i=\frac{X_i-\mu}{\sigma\lambda}\in(-1,1),
\]

produces a likelihood with a **fixed** support \((-1,1)\).  
Under this parametrisation the log‑likelihood satisfies the standard regularity conditions, the Fisher‑information matrix \(I(\phi)\) is finite and non‑singular in a neighbourhood of the true value \(\phi_{0}=(\mu_{0},\sigma_{0},\lambda_{0})\), and

\[
\sqrt{n}\bigl(\hat\phi_{n}-\phi_{0}\bigr)\;\xrightarrow{d}\;
N\!\bigl(0,\;I(\phi_{0})^{-1}\bigr).
\]

The matrix \(I(\phi_{0})\) can be written explicitly in terms of the standard normal pdf \(\varphi(\cdot)\) and cdf \(\Phi(\cdot)\) evaluated at \(\pm\lambda_{0}\).

---

### 1.  Why the usual regularity conditions fail  

The density of a single observation in the original parameters is  

\[
f_{X}(x\mid\mu,\sigma,\lambda)
   =\frac{1}{\sigma}\,
     \frac{\varphi\!\bigl((x-\mu)/\sigma\bigr)}
          {2\Phi(\lambda)-1}\,
     \mathbf 1\!\Bigl\{\bigl|(x-\mu)/\sigma\bigr|<\lambda\Bigr\},
\tag{1}
\]

where \(\varphi(z)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-z^{2}/2}\) and \(\Phi(z)=\int_{-\infty}^{z}\varphi(t)\,dt\).  
The indicator in (1) makes the support \(\{x:| (x-\mu)/\sigma|<\lambda\}\) depend on \((\mu,\sigma,\lambda)\). Consequently the score vector does not have mean zero and the usual expression  

\[
I(\phi)=\mathbb{E}_{\phi}\!\Bigl[\nabla_{\phi}\log f_{X}\,
                                 \nabla_{\phi}\log f_{X}^{\!\top}\Bigr]
\]

need not exist. Hence the classical theorem that the MLE is asymptotically normal cannot be applied directly.

---

### 2.  Re‑parameterisation with a fixed support  

Define  

\[
W_i=\frac{X_i-\mu}{\sigma\lambda}\in(-1,1).
\]

The Jacobian of the transformation is \(|dx/dw|=\sigma\lambda\).  
Using (1) we obtain the density of \(W_i\) that no longer depends on the support:

\[
f_{W}(w\mid\mu,\sigma,\lambda)
   =\lambda\,
     \frac{\varphi(\lambda w)}{2\Phi(\lambda)-1}\,
     \mathbf 1\{-1<w<1\}.
\tag{2}
\]

Now the support is the fixed interval \((-1,1)\); the likelihood is a smooth function of \(\phi\) and satisfies the usual regularity conditions.

---

### 3.  Log‑likelihood and score functions  

For a single observation the log‑likelihood (ignoring the constant \(\log\mathbf 1\{-1<w<1\}\)) is  

\[
\ell(\mu,\sigma,\lambda;w)
   =\log\lambda-\frac12(\lambda w)^{2}
    -\log\!\bigl(2\Phi(\lambda)-1\bigr)-\log\sigma .
\tag{3}
\]

Introduce the standardized variable \(Z=\lambda w=(X-\mu)/\sigma\); under the true parameters \(Z\) has the truncated‑standard‑normal density  

\[
f_{Z}(z)=\frac{\varphi(z)}{\Delta(\lambda)},
\qquad 
\Delta(\lambda)=2\Phi(\lambda)-1,\qquad |z|<\lambda .
\tag{4}
\]

The three components of the score are

\[
\begin{aligned}
s_{\mu}&=\frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\mu}= \frac{Z}{\sigma},\\[4pt]
s_{\sigma}&=\frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\sigma}= \frac{Z^{2}-1}{\sigma},\\[4pt]
s_{\lambda}&=\frac{\partial\ell}{\partial\lambda}
            =\frac{1-Z^{2}}{\lambda}
             -\frac{2\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)} .
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

Because the distribution of \(Z\) is symmetric around zero, all mixed expectations that involve an odd power of \(Z\) vanish, which greatly simplifies the Fisher information.

---

### 4.  Moments of the truncated standard normal  

Define  

\[
\alpha(\lambda)=\frac{2\lambda\,\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)} .
\]

Then  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}[Z^{2}] &= 1-\alpha(\lambda),\\[4pt]
\mathbb{E}[Z^{4}] &= 3-\frac{2\lambda(\lambda^{2}+3)\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)} .
\end{aligned}
\tag{6}
\]

Consequently  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\!\bigl[(Z^{2}-1)^{2}\bigr] 
   &=\mathbb{E}[Z^{4}]-2\mathbb{E}[Z^{2}]+1
    =2-2\lambda(\lambda^{2}+1)\frac{\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)} .
\end{aligned}
\tag{7}
\]

Also  

\[
\mathbb{E}[1-Z^{2}]=\alpha(\lambda)=\frac{2\lambda\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)} .
\tag{8}
\]

---

### 5.  Fisher‑information matrix  

Using \(I_{jk}= \mathbb{E}[s_{j}s_{k}]\) and the moments above we obtain, for a generic \(\phi=(\mu,\sigma,\lambda)\),

\[
I(\phi)=
\begin{pmatrix}
\displaystyle \frac{1-\alpha(\lambda)}{\sigma^{2}} &
0 &
0 \\[12pt]
0 &
\displaystyle \frac{2-2\lambda(\lambda^{2}+1)\frac{\varphi(\lambda)}{\Delta(\lambda)}}{\sigma^{2}} &
\displaystyle -\frac{2}{\sigma\lambda}
      +\frac{2(\lambda^{2}+1)\varphi(\lambda)}{\sigma\Delta(\lambda)}
      +\frac{4\lambda\varphi^{2}(\lambda)}{\sigma\Delta^{2}(\lambda)} \\[14pt]
0 &
\displaystyle -\frac{2}{\sigma\lambda}
      +\frac{2(\lambda^{2}+1)\varphi(\lambda)}{\sigma\Delta(\lambda)}
      +\frac{4\lambda\varphi^{2}(\lambda)}{\sigma\Delta^{2}(\lambda)} &
\displaystyle \frac{2}{\lambda^{2}}
      -\frac{2(\lambda^{2}+1)\varphi(\lambda)}{\lambda\Delta(\lambda)}
      -\frac{4\varphi^{2}(\lambda)}{\Delta^{2}(\lambda)}
\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{9}
\]

All entries are finite and the matrix is positive‑definite for every \(\lambda>0\); in particular it is non‑singular in a neighbourhood of the true value \(\phi_{0}\).

---

### 6.  Asymptotic distribution of the MLE  

Standard results for regular parametric families (e.g. Theorem 5.39 in *van der Vaart, 1998*) now apply to the re‑parameterised likelihood. Hence the joint MLE \(\hat\phi_{n}=(\hat\mu_{n},\hat\sigma_{n},\hat\lambda_{n})\) is consistent and

\[
\boxed{\;
\sqrt{n}\bigl(\hat\phi_{n}-\phi_{0}\bigr)
   \;\xrightarrow{d}\;
   N\!\bigl(0,\;I(\phi_{0})^{-1}\bigr)\;
}
\]

with the Fisher‑information matrix \(I(\phi_{0})\) given by (9) after substituting \(\lambda=\lambda_{0}\), \(\sigma=\sigma_{0}\) and the corresponding values of the standard normal pdf \(\varphi(\lambda_{0})\) and cdf \(\Phi(\lambda_{0})\).

Thus, after the appropriate re‑parameterisation that removes the dependence of the support on the parameters, the MLE of \((\mu,\sigma^{2},\lambda)\) is asymptotically normal with covariance matrix equal to the inverse of the explicit information matrix (9).

---

**Step 5: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
*Premise*: The transformed model $(W_i; \phi)$ satisfies the regularity conditions:

- Likelihood is twice continuously differentiable in $\phi$,  
- Fisher information is finite and non-singular,  
- Parameter space is open in $\mathbb{R}^3_+$.

$$
\sqrt{n}(\hat{\phi}_n - \phi_0) \xrightarrow{d} N\left(0, I(\phi_0)^{-1}\right),
$$
where $I(\phi_0)$ is the Fisher information matrix evaluated at the true parameter $\phi_0 = (\mu_0, \sigma_0, \lambda_0)$, with entries as derived.

*Intermediate Conclusion*: Despite the original model violating classical regularity, the transformation to $W_i$ restores regularity, enabling asymptotic normality.

- *Hypothesis 1 (Alternative Reparameterization)*: One might consider reparameterizing in terms of $a$ and $b$ instead of $\lambda$, treating $a = \mu - \lambda\sigma$, $b = \mu + \lambda\sigma$ as separate parameters. The Fisher information matrix $I(\phi_0)$ is explicitly derived and non-singular for all $\lambda_0 > 0$, ensuring that $\sqrt{n}(\hat{\phi}_n - \phi_0) \xrightarrow{d} N(0, I(\phi_0)^{-1})$. The firm must decide whether to *transplant* the disruptive technology into its production process at a sunk cost $ K $, or to *maintain* the conventional technology.

Assume that consumer surplus depends on the quality $ Q $ of the product, which is a function of the technology adopted: $ Q = \alpha + \beta \cdot \mathbb{I}_{\text{disruptive}} $, with $ \alpha > 0 $, $ \beta > 0 $. The firm’s profit function in period $ t $ is given by $ \pi_t = (p_t - C_t)q_t - K \cdot \mathbb{I}_{\text{transplant at } t} $, where $ p_t $ is the price set by the firm, $ q_t $ is the quantity produced, and $ \mathbb{I} $ is the indicator function. The market demand is $ q_t = D(p_t) = A - B p_t $, with $ A, B > 0 $.

**Optimal stopping rule**

The monopolist should transplant the disruptive technology the first time the observed unit‑cost \(C_{t}\) falls at or below a critical level \(C^{*}\),

\[
\boxed{ \; C_{t}\le C^{*}\; } ,
\]

where \(C^{*}\) is the unique solution of the **value‑matching** condition  

\[
\underbrace{-K-\delta}_{\text{one‑off cost}}+\widetilde G(C^{*},T)
   =\frac{1-e^{-rT}}{r}\,\Pi(c_{0})
     +e^{-rT}\,\widetilde V(C^{*}),
\tag{1}
\]

together with the **smooth‑pasting** condition  

\[
\frac{\partial \widetilde G}{\partial C}(C^{*},T)
   =e^{-rT}\,\frac{\partial \widetilde V}{\partial C}(C^{*}).
\tag{2}
\]

All terms are obtained analytically from the linear‑quadratic profit function  

\[
\Pi(C)=\frac{(A-BC)^{2}}{4B},
\]

the Ornstein‑Uhlenbeck cost dynamics  

\[
C_{t+T}\mid C_{t}=c\;\sim\;
\mathcal N\!\Bigl(m(c,T),\,s^{2}(T)\Bigr),\qquad
m(c,T)=\mu+(c-\mu)e^{-\theta T},\;
s^{2}(T)=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{2\theta}\!\bigl(1-e^{-2\theta T}\bigr),
\]

and the prospect‑theory probability‑weighting  

\[
w(p)=\frac{p^{\gamma}}{p^{\gamma}+(1-p)^{\gamma}},\qquad \gamma<1 .
\]

Define the **distorted moments** of a standard normal variable \(Z\),

\[
\kappa_{1}(\gamma)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}z\,d\Phi_{\gamma}(z),\qquad
\kappa_{2}(\gamma)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}z^{2}\,d\Phi_{\gamma}(z)-\kappa_{1}(\gamma)^{2},
\]

with \(\Phi_{\gamma}(x)=w\!\bigl(\Phi(x)\bigr)\) and \(\Phi\) the ordinary normal CDF.  
Using these moments, the **distorted finite‑horizon profit** and the **distorted perpetual profit** are

\[
\widetilde G(c,T)=\frac{1-e^{-rT}}{r}\;
\frac{1}{4B}\Bigl[ A^{2}
            -2AB\bigl(m(c,T)+s(T)\kappa_{1}\bigr)
            +B^{2}\bigl(m(c,T)^{2}+s^{2}(T)+2m(c,T)s(T)\kappa_{1}+s^{2}(T)\kappa_{2}\bigr)
          \Bigr],
\tag{3}
\]

\[
\widetilde V(c)=\frac{1}{r}\;
\frac{1}{4B}\Bigl[ A^{2}
            -2AB\bigl(\mu+s_{\infty}\kappa_{1}\bigr)
            +B^{2}\bigl(\mu^{2}+s_{\infty}^{2}+2\mu s_{\infty}\kappa_{1}+s_{\infty}^{2}\kappa_{2}\bigr)
          \Bigr],
\tag{4}
\]

where \(s_{\infty}^{2}= \sigma^{2}/(2\theta)\) is the stationary variance of the OU process.

Substituting (3)–(4) into (1)–(2) yields an implicit equation for \(C^{*}\). Solving for \(C^{*}\) gives the **threshold expression**

\[
\boxed{
C^{*}= \frac{A}{B}
      -\frac{2}{B}\,
        \frac{ \displaystyle 
               \frac{1-e^{-rT}}{r}\,\Pi(c_{0})
               +e^{-rT}\,\widetilde V(\mu)
               -K-\delta
               -\frac{1-e^{-rT}}{r}\,
                 \frac{B^{2}}{4B}\bigl[2\mu s_{\infty}\kappa_{1}+s_{\infty}^{2}\kappa_{2}\bigr]
               }
               { \displaystyle 
               \frac{A-B\mu}{2}
               -\frac{B}{2}\bigl(s_{\infty}\kappa_{1}\bigr)
               } } .
\tag{5}
\]

Equation (5) makes the dependence of the stopping rule transparent:

| Parameter | Effect on \(C^{*}\) (and thus on the transplant decision) |
|-----------|------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Mean‑reversion speed \(\theta\)** | Larger \(\theta\) ⇒ smaller stationary variance \(s_{\infty}^{2}\) ⇒ the distortion term shrinks ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises** (the firm waits longer). |
| **Volatility \(\sigma\)** | Increases \(s_{\infty}^{2}\) ⇒ the overweighted low‑cost tail (through \(\kappa_{1}<0\), \(\kappa_{2}<1\)) becomes more valuable ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **falls** (earlier adoption). |
| **Planning horizon \(T\)** | Shorter \(T\) reduces the discounted benefit of waiting \(\frac{1-e^{-rT}}{r}\) ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises** (more myopic). |
| **Distortion exponent \(\gamma\) (<1)** | Smaller \(\gamma\) ⇒ stronger overweighting of low‑probability low‑cost outcomes ⇒ \(|\kappa_{1}|\) grows, \(\kappa_{2}\) falls ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **falls**. |
| **Inertia penalty \(\delta\)** | Directly adds to the transplant cost side of (1) ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises** (delays adoption). |
| **Sunk cost \(K\)** | Larger \(K\) raises the cost of transplantation ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises**. |
| **Demand intercept \(A\) / slope \(B\)** | Higher \(A\) (or lower \(B\)) raises conventional profit \(\Pi(c_{0})\) ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises**; a larger \(B\) magnifies the marginal profit loss from a higher cost, making the denominator larger and thus **lowering** \(C^{*}\). |
| **Quality premium \(\beta\)** | Enters \(\Pi(\cdot)\) through a higher willingness‑to‑pay after transplantation; it raises the discounted future profit term \(\widetilde V(\mu)\) ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **falls**. |
| **Baseline conventional cost \(c_{0}\)** | Higher \(c_{0}\) raises \(\Pi(c_{0})\) (the “stay‑put” payoff) ⇒ \(C^{*}\) **rises**. |

---

### When the firm *fails to transplant* despite social optimality

The socially optimal adoption cost \(C^{\text{soc}}\) is the level at which the *expected* (unweighted) discounted social surplus from the disruptive technology exceeds that from the conventional one. Because the private rule (5) contains three upward‑biasing elements—(i) the inertia penalty \(\delta\), (ii) the finite horizon \(T\) (myopia), and (iii) the objective‑probability component of profit (i.e., the term \(\Pi(c_{0})\) that is not reduced by the distortion)—it can happen that

\[
C^{*} \;>\; C^{\text{soc}} .
\]

In this regime the cost process, even when it drifts toward its long‑run mean \(\mu\), never reaches the lower private threshold before the horizon expires or before the firm incurs the inertia penalty; consequently the firm never transplants. The inequality is more likely when:

* \(\theta\) is large (fast mean‑reversion, so future upside is limited);
* \(\sigma\) is small (low volatility, reducing the overweighted upside);
* \(\gamma\) is close to 1 (weak probability distortion);
* \(\delta\) or \(K\) are sizable;
* the planning horizon \(T\) is short.

---

### Implications for industrial organization and innovation policy

1. **Behavioural lock‑in** – Managerial myopia and probability distortion create a systematic bias that can lock firms into an inferior technology even when the socially optimal switch is imminent.
2. **Role of volatility** – Counter‑intuitively, higher technological uncertainty (larger \(\sigma\)) can *facilitate* adoption because risk‑averse managers over‑weight low‑cost tail events.
3. **Policy levers**  
   * **Subsidies or tax credits** that lower the effective transplant cost \(K\) or the inertia penalty \(\delta\) shift the threshold downward, aligning private and social decisions.  
   * **Information campaigns** that correct probability weighting (e.g., presenting realistic cost‑distribution forecasts) increase \(\gamma\) toward 1, reducing the distortion bias and preventing premature abandonment of the conventional technology when it is still optimal.  
   * **Regulatory mandates** that shorten the effective planning horizon (forcing a longer evaluation window) or impose a deadline can eliminate the myopic term \(T\), moving the private rule closer to the perpetual‑option benchmark.

In sum, the optimal stopping rule (5) captures how stochastic cost dynamics, behavioural evaluation, and organisational frictions jointly determine the timing of disruptive‑technology adoption. When the combined effect of inertia, myopia, and weak distortion pushes the private threshold above the socially optimal cost, firms will under‑invest in innovation, suggesting a clear rationale for targeted policy interventions.

# Think

### **Introduction: Problem Framing and Core Challenge**

This problem centers on a monopolistic firm's dynamic decision to adopt a disruptive technology under conditions of **stochastic cost evolution**, **managerial bounded rationality**, and **organizational inertia**. The firm faces a binary choice: maintain a conventional technology with known cost $ c_0 $, or incur a sunk cost $ K $ to transplant a disruptive technology whose marginal cost $ C_t $ follows a mean-reverting Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process. The decision is further complicated by three behavioral and structural frictions:

1. **Managerial myopia**: The firm evaluates future profits over a finite horizon $ T $, discounting at rate $ r $, and uses a *distorted probability weighting function* $ w(p) = \frac{p^\gamma}{p^\gamma + (1-p)^\gamma} $ with $ \gamma < 1 $, which systematically overweights low-probability high-impact events (i.e., very low-cost realizations).
2. **Organizational inertia**: A one-time penalty $ \delta > 0 $ is imposed if the firm delays the transplant beyond the optimal moment.
3. **Social vs. private optimality**: The socially optimal adoption threshold $ C^{\text{soc}} $ may be lower than the firm’s private threshold $ C^* $, leading to under-adoption even when the disruptive technology eventually becomes superior.

The goal is to derive the **optimal stopping rule**—a threshold $ C^* $ on the current cost $ C_t $—such that the firm should adopt the disruptive technology the first time $ C_t \le C^* $. The analysis must trace how $ C^* $ depends on the interplay among technological uncertainty ($ \theta, \sigma $), behavioral bias ($ \gamma $), organizational constraints ($ \delta $), demand parameters ($ A, B $), and cost structure ($ c_0, \alpha, \beta, K $).

---

### **Main Discussion: Step-by-Step Reasoning with Enhanced Structure**

#### **Step 1: Foundation – Profit Maximization under Linear Demand**

- **Premise**: Market demand is $ q_t = A - B p_t $, inverse demand: $ p_t = \frac{A - q_t}{B} $.
- **Inference**: Substituting into the profit function $ \pi_t = (p_t - C_t) q_t $, we obtain:
  $$
  \pi_t = \left( \frac{A - q_t}{B} - C_t \right) q_t = \frac{A q_t}{B} - \frac{q_t^2}{B} - C_t q_t.
  $$
- **Intermediate Conclusion**: First-order condition yields optimal output:
  $$
  q^*(C_t) = \frac{A - B C_t}{2}.
  $$
  The maximal per-period profit (as a function of marginal cost) is:
  $$
  \Pi(C_t) = \frac{(A - B C_t)^2}{4B}.
  $$
  This quadratic form is key: **lower $ C_t $ increases $ \Pi(C_t) $**, and since $ \Pi $ is convex in $ C_t $, the firm benefits disproportionately from low-cost realizations.

> 📌 *Insight*: The profit function is **quadratic and decreasing in $ C_t $**, making the left tail of the cost distribution (very low $ C_t $) highly valuable. This sets the stage for distortion effects.

---

#### **Step 2: Dynamic Framework – Finite-Horizon Optimal Stopping with Distortion**

- **Premise**: The firm chooses between two options at each $ t $:
  - **Transplant now**: Pay sunk cost $ K $, incur inertia penalty $ \delta $ if delayed, and receive the *distorted* expected discounted future profit stream from the disruptive technology.
  - **Wait**: Continue with conventional technology (profit $ \Pi(c_0) $) for $ T $ periods, then face the continuation value with a distorted expectation.
- **Inference**: The decision is modeled as a finite-horizon optimal stopping problem with a **distorted expectation operator** $ \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}_t[\cdot] $, replacing the standard $ \mathbb{E}_t[\cdot] $. This reflects **prospect theory-inspired myopia**: the manager treats probability distributions non-linearly, amplifying the perceived value of rare low-cost events.

> 📌 *Creative Insight*: The distortion $ w(p) $ acts as a **non-linear filter** on risk perception. For $ \gamma < 1 $, it assigns higher weight to tail events (e.g., $ C_t $ dropping to $ \mu - 3\sigma $), effectively **increasing the expected value of waiting** when uncertainty is high—contrary to risk aversion.

---

#### **Step 3: Stochastic Cost Dynamics – OU Process and Transition Distributions**

- **Premise**: $ C_t $ follows an OU process:
  $$
  dC_t = \theta(\mu - C_t) dt + \sigma dW_t, \quad \theta > 0, \sigma > 0.
  $$
- **Inference**: The process is stationary, with:
  - Long-term mean: $ \mu $
  - Stationary variance: $ s_\infty^2 = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\theta} $
  - Transition distribution: $ C_{t+T} \mid C_t = c \sim \mathcal{N}(m(c,T), s^2(T)) $, where:
    $$
    m(c,T) = \mu + (c - \mu)e^{-\theta T}, \quad s^2(T) = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\theta}(1 - e^{-2\theta T}).
    $$
- **Intermediate Conclusion**: The future cost is **Gaussian and conditionally mean-reverting**. This structure allows analytical treatment of the distorted expectation.

---

#### **Step 4: Incorporating Probability Distortion via Weighted Moments**

- **Premise**: The manager’s expectation is distorted: $ \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}[h(C)] = \int h(c)\, d\Phi_\gamma((c - m)/s) $, where $ \Phi_\gamma(x) = w(\Phi(x)) $.
- **Inference**: For a Gaussian $ C_{t+T} $, the **distorted first and second moments** are:
  $$
  \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{t+T}] = m(c,T) + s(T)\, \kappa_1(\gamma), \quad
  \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{t+T}^2] = m(c,T)^2 + s(T)^2 + 2m(c,T)s(T)\kappa_1(\gamma) + s(T)^2 \kappa_2(\gamma),
  $$
  where $ \kappa_1(\gamma) < 0 $, $ \kappa_2(\gamma) < 1 $ for $ \gamma < 1 $—due to overweighting of the left tail.

> 📌 *Counterargument Consideration*: Could $ \kappa_1 > 0 $? No—since $ w(p) > p $ for $ p < 0.5 $, the left tail is inflated, so the **distorted mean shifts left** (i.e., lower expected cost), increasing the perceived value of waiting.

---

#### **Step 5: Constructing the Distorted Value Functions**

- **Premise**: The firm’s value function must satisfy the **value-matching** and **smooth-pasting** conditions at the threshold $ C^* $.

##### **(a) Distorted Continuation Value (Wait)**  
$$
\widetilde{G}(c,T) := \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}_t\left[\int_0^T e^{-rs} \Pi(C_{t+s}) ds\right].
$$
Using linearity of the integral and the quadratic form of $ \Pi $, we write:
$$
\widetilde{G}(c,T) = \frac{1 - e^{-rT}}{r} \cdot \frac{1}{4B} \left[ A^2 - 2AB \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{t+T}] + B^2 \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{t+T}^2] \right].
$$

##### **(b) Distorted Post-Adoption Value (Transplant)**  
After adoption, the firm remains in the disruptive regime. The infinite-horizon expected profit is:
$$
\widetilde{V}(c) := \widetilde{\mathbb{E}}_c\left[\int_0^\infty e^{-rs} \Pi(C_s) ds\right] = \frac{1}{r} \cdot \frac{1}{4B} \left[ A^2 - 2AB \widetilde{m}_\infty + B^2 \widetilde{m}_2^\infty \right],
$$
where $ \widetilde{m}_\infty = \mu + s_\infty \kappa_1(\gamma) $, $ \widetilde{m}_2^\infty = \mu^2 + s_\infty^2 + 2\mu s_\infty \kappa_1(\gamma) + s_\infty^2 \kappa_2(\gamma) $, and $ s_\infty^2 = \frac{\sigma^2}{2\theta} $.

> 📌 *New Insight*: The stationary distortion shifts the **long-run expected cost downward**, effectively increasing the firm’s willingness to wait. This is **not** due to lower risk, but to **systematic overvaluation of rare upside events**.

---

#### **Step 6: Deriving the Threshold via Value-Matching and Smooth-Pasting**

- **Premise**: At the optimal threshold $ C^* $, the firm is indifferent between transplanting now and waiting:
  $$
  -K - \delta + \widetilde{G}(C^*, T) = \frac{1 - e^{-rT}}{r} \Pi(c_0) + e^{-rT} \widetilde{V}(C^*).
  $$
  This is the **value-matching condition**.

- **Inference**: The derivative of both sides must also match (smooth-pasting), ensuring no arbitrage:
  $$
  \frac{\partial \widetilde{G}}{\partial C}(C^*, T) = e^{-rT} \frac{\partial \widetilde{V}}{\partial C}(C^*).
  $$

- **Intermediate Conclusion**: The derivative of $ \widetilde{G} $ w.r.t. $ C^* $ depends on $ \kappa_1(\gamma) $, and the derivative of $ \widetilde{V} $ depends on the stationary distortion. Solving both equations yields a **unique** $ C^* $, implicitly defined.

> 📌 *Formula Derivation*: Substituting the expressions for $ \widetilde{G} $ and $ \widetilde{V} $, we solve for $ C^* $:

$$
\boxed{
C^* = \frac{A}{B} - \frac{2}{B} \cdot \frac{
    \frac{1 - e^{-rT}}{r} \Pi(c_0)
    + e^{-rT} \widetilde{V}(\mu)
    - K - \delta
    - \frac{1 - e^{-rT}}{r} \cdot \frac{B^2}{4B} \left(2 \mu s_\infty \kappa_1 + s_\infty^2 \kappa_2 \right)
}{
    \frac{A - B \mu}{2} - \frac{B}{2} s_\infty \kappa_1
}
}
$$

This **closed-form threshold** explicitly captures all structural and behavioral parameters.

---

#### **Step 7: Parameter Sensitivity and Economic Interpretation**

| Parameter | Effect on $ C^* $ | Mechanism |
|---------|-------------------|---------|
| **$ \theta $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Faster mean-reversion → less volatility → less upside from waiting → delay adoption |
| **$ \sigma $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↓ | Higher variance → more extreme low-cost events → stronger distortion effect → earlier adoption |
| **$ T $ ↓** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Shorter horizon → less future reward → less incentive to wait |
| **$ \gamma $ ↓** | $ C^* $ ↓ | Stronger probability distortion → greater overweighting of tail events → earlier adoption |
| **$ \delta $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Inertia penalty increases cost of delay → firm waits longer |
| **$ K $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Higher sunk cost → delayed adoption |
| **$ A $ ↑ or $ B $ ↓** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Higher conventional profit → more attractive to stay |
| **$ \beta $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↓ | Higher quality premium → greater benefit from adoption |
| **$ c_0 $ ↑** | $ C^* $ ↑ | Higher conventional cost → lower status quo payoff → more incentive to switch |

> 📌 *Counterintuitive Insight*: **Higher technological uncertainty ($ \sigma $) lowers the threshold**—a rare case where *risk* promotes innovation, not deterrence. This arises because **distortion amplifies the value of rare good outcomes**, turning volatility into a catalyst.

---

#### **Step 8: Failure to Adopt Despite Social Optimality**

- **Premise**: The socially optimal adoption cost $ C^{\text{soc}} $ is defined by equating the *expected* discounted social surplus from both technologies (ignoring $ \delta $, $ K $, and distortion).
- **Inference**: The private threshold $ C^* $ includes **three upward biases**:
  1. **Inertia penalty $ \delta $** (adds to cost of adoption)
  2. **Finite horizon $ T $** (reduces future benefits)
  3. **Distorted expectation** (overweights low-probability events, but only *after* the firm has already adopted—so it doesn’t fully correct for under-investment).

> 📌 *Critical Finding*: Even if $ \mu < C^{\text{soc}} $, if $ C^* > C^{\text{soc}} $, the firm **never adopts**. This occurs when:
- $ \theta $ is large (costs revert too fast),
- $ \sigma $ is small (limited upside),
- $ T $ is short,
- $ \gamma \to 1 $ (weak distortion),
- $ \delta $ or $ K $ is large.

Thus, **the firm fails to adopt despite the disruptive technology being socially optimal**—a classic case of **private underinvestment in innovation**.

---

### **Conclusion: Synthesis and Policy Implications**

- **Primary Hypothesis**: The optimal stopping rule is a **distorted finite-horizon real-options threshold**, where the firm adopts the disruptive technology when $ C_t \le C^* $, with $ C^* $ determined by a combination of technological uncertainty, behavioral distortion, organizational inertia, and demand structure. The threshold is **lower** when volatility is high, distortion is strong, or quality premium is large.

- **Alternative Hypotheses**:
  - *Hypothesis 1 (Robustness to model choice)*: A simulation-based policy iteration would confirm the analytical result but could not yield closed-form insight. The chosen approach trades exactness for transparency.
  - *Hypothesis 2 (Inertia as a feedback loop)*: If $ \delta $ is state-dependent and increases with delay (e.g., due to skill degradation), $ C^* $ would rise even further, potentially leading to **irreversible lock-in**.

- **Conclusion**: The firm may **fail to adopt** the disruptive technology even when it is socially optimal, due to the **combined effect of organizational inertia ($ \delta $), managerial myopia ($ T $), and insufficient probability distortion**. This creates a **systematic innovation gap** in industrial organization.

- **Policy Implications**:
  - **Subsidies** that reduce $ K $ or $ \delta $ shift $ C^* $ downward, aligning private and social incentives.
  - **Information campaigns** that correct probability weighting (e.g., by presenting realistic cost distributions) can reduce $ \gamma $-driven distortions.
  - **Regulatory deadlines** or **mandatory technology reviews** can counteract myopia by extending the effective planning horizon.

> 📌 *Final Insight*: In dynamic markets with incomplete information and behavioral frictions, **innovation is not just a technical challenge, but a cognitive and organizational one**. The optimal stopping rule is not just a number—it is a **reflection of managerial psychology, institutional structure, and market design**.

― End ―

# Think

---

### **Introduction: Problem Context and Asymptotic Regime**

We analyze the asymptotic behavior of the Fisher information matrix $\mathcal{I}(\mu, \sigma)$ for a single observation from a truncated normal distribution $X \sim \mathcal{TN}(\mu, \sigma^2, a, b)$, where the truncation bounds are parameter-dependent:
$$
a = \mu - \alpha\sigma, \quad b = \mu + \beta\sigma, \quad \alpha > 0, \beta > 0,
$$
with the constraint $\alpha\beta = \gamma > 0$ held constant as $\alpha \to 0^+$, $\beta \to \infty$. This degenerate limit corresponds to a shrinking lower tail (near the lower bound) and a diverging upper tail, with fixed geometric product $\gamma$. The goal is to derive the leading-order asymptotic expansion of the Fisher information matrix, with particular focus on the off-diagonal term $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$, which is shown to diverge logarithmically in $\alpha$. We aim to compute the first three terms in powers of $\log(1/\alpha)$ and identify the exact coefficient of the $\log(1/\alpha)$ term in terms of $\gamma$.

---

### **Main Discussion: Step-by-Step Reasoning**

#### **Step 1: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise:** The Fisher information matrix is defined as $\mathcal{I}(\mu, \sigma) = \mathbb{E}\left[ \nabla_\theta \ell \cdot \nabla_\theta \ell^\top \right]$, where $\theta = (\mu, \sigma)^\top$, and $\ell(\mu, \sigma)$ is the log-likelihood. For the truncated normal, the density is:
$$
f_X(x \mid \mu, \sigma) = \frac{1}{\sigma D(\alpha, \beta)} \phi\left( \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \right), \quad x \in (a, b),
$$
with $D(\alpha, \beta) = \Phi(\beta) - \Phi(-\alpha)$, $\phi(t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-t^2/2}$, and $\Phi(t)$ the standard normal CDF.

**Inference:** The score vector components are:
$$
s_\mu = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma^2} + \frac{\phi(\alpha)}{\sigma D}, \quad
s_\sigma = -\frac{1}{\sigma} + \frac{(x - \mu)^2}{\sigma^3} + \frac{\alpha \phi(\alpha)}{\sigma D}.
$$
Standardizing $Z = (X - \mu)/\sigma$, we express the information matrix in terms of truncated moments $m_k = \mathbb{E}[Z^k \mid -\alpha < Z < \beta]$.

**Intermediate Conclusion:** The Fisher information entries are:
$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\mu} = \frac{1}{\sigma^2}(m_2 - m_1^2), \quad
\mathcal{I}_{\sigma\sigma} = \frac{1}{\sigma^2}(m_4 - 2m_2 + 1), \quad
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma} = \frac{1}{\sigma^2}(m_3 - m_1 m_2) - \left( \partial_\mu \log D \right)\left( \partial_\sigma \log D \right).
$$

---

#### **Step 2: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise:** As $\alpha \to 0^+$, $\beta = \gamma / \alpha \to \infty$, with $\gamma$ fixed. Thus, $\phi(\beta) = O(e^{-\gamma^2/(2\alpha^2)})$ is *exponentially small* and negligible in any algebraic expansion. The normalization constant becomes:
$$
D(\alpha, \beta) = \Phi(\beta) - \Phi(-\alpha) = 1 - \Phi(-\alpha) = \Phi(\alpha),
$$
since $\Phi(\beta) \to 1$. Using $\Phi(\alpha) = \frac{1}{2} + \phi(0)\alpha + O(\alpha^3)$, we get:
$$
D = \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \alpha + O(\alpha^3), \quad
\frac{1}{D} = 2\left[1 - 4\phi(0)\alpha + O(\alpha^2)\right].
$$

**Inference:** The first few moments expand algebraically:
- $m_1 = \dfrac{\phi(\alpha)}{D} = 2\phi(0) + O(\alpha)$,
- $m_2 = 1 + \dfrac{\alpha \phi(\alpha)}{D} = 1 + 2\phi(0)\alpha + O(\alpha^2)$,
- $m_3 = m_1(2 + \alpha^2) = 4\phi(0) + O(\alpha)$,
- $m_4 = 3 + O(\alpha)$.

**Intermediate Conclusion:** The bulk contribution to $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$, derived from these expansions, is $O(1)$ and *does not contain logarithmic terms*. Hence, the logarithmic divergence must arise from a **boundary-layer effect** near $z = -\alpha$, where the truncation cuts off the density.

---

#### **Step 3: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise:** Consider the contribution to $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ from the interval $[-\alpha, -\alpha + \delta]$, where $\alpha \ll \delta \ll 1$. Define $z = -\alpha + u$, $u \in (0, \delta)$, so that:
$$
\phi(z) = \phi(-\alpha + u) = \phi(0) \exp\left[ -\tfrac{1}{2}(\alpha - u)^2 \right] = \phi(0) e^{-\alpha u + \frac{1}{2}u^2} e^{-\frac{1}{2}\alpha^2}.
$$
Since $\alpha \to 0$, $e^{-\frac{1}{2}\alpha^2} = 1 + O(\alpha^2)$, and we expand:
$$
\phi(z) \approx \phi(0) \left(1 + \alpha u + \frac{1}{2}(\alpha u)^2 + \cdots \right) e^{\frac{1}{2}u^2} \quad \text{(but } e^{\frac{1}{2}u^2} \text{ is } O(1)\text{)}.
$$

**Inference:** The key term in the integrand $s_\mu s_\sigma$ involves:
$$
z^3 - z \approx (-\alpha)^3 + 3\alpha^2 u - 3\alpha u^2 + u^3 + \alpha - u = \alpha(1 - 3u^2) + 3\alpha^2 u + u^3 - \alpha^3 - 3\alpha u^2.
$$
When multiplied by the density $\phi(z)/D$, the dominant singular behavior arises from the term:
$$
\frac{1}{\sigma^2} \int_0^\delta \left[ \text{polynomial in } u \right] \cdot \frac{\phi(z)}{D} \, du.
$$
The most singular term comes from $u^{-1}$-like behavior when $\phi(z)$ is expanded to first order in $u$. Specifically, since:
$$
\phi(z) \sim \phi(0) e^{-\alpha u} \quad \text{as } \alpha \to 0, u \to 0,
$$
and $e^{-\alpha u} \approx 1 - \alpha u + \cdots$, we get:
$$
\phi(z) \sim \phi(0) \left(1 - \alpha u + \cdots \right).
$$
But to extract the logarithmic divergence, we must consider the **exact exponential decay**:
$$
\int_0^\delta \frac{e^{-\alpha u}}{u} \, du \sim \int_0^\delta \frac{1}{u} \, du - \alpha \int_0^\delta 1 \, du + \cdots = \log\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}\right) + \log\left(\frac{\delta}{\alpha}\right) + \text{const} + o(1),
$$
provided $\delta$ is chosen such that $\delta \gg \alpha$, e.g., $\delta = \alpha^\epsilon$, $0 < \epsilon < 1$. Thus:
$$
\int_0^\delta \frac{\phi(z)}{D} \, du \sim \frac{2\phi(0)}{\sigma^2} \int_0^\delta \frac{1}{u} \, du = \frac{2\phi(0)}{\sigma^2} \log\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}\right) + O(1).
$$

**Intermediate Conclusion:** The logarithmic divergence in $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ originates from the **boundary-layer integral** near $z = -\alpha$, where the density is sharply truncated and the polynomial part of the score product yields a $1/u$ singularity when expanded in $u$.

---

#### **Step 4: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise:** To compute the **leading three terms** in $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ in powers of $\log(1/\alpha)$, we evaluate:
$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}^{(\mathcal{B})} = \frac{1}{\sigma^2} \int_{-\alpha}^{-\alpha + \delta} \left( z^3 - z \right) \frac{\phi(z)}{D} \, dz.
$$
Set $z = -\alpha + u$, $u \in (0, \delta)$, so:
$$
z^3 - z = (-\alpha + u)^3 + \alpha - u = -\alpha^3 + 3\alpha^2 u - 3\alpha u^2 + u^3 + \alpha - u.
$$
The leading term is $\alpha$, which gives:
$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}^{(\mathcal{B})} \sim \frac{1}{\sigma^2 D} \int_0^\delta \left[ \alpha + \text{higher} \right] \phi(-\alpha + u) \, du.
$$
But now, to get the logarithmic term, consider the **first-order correction** in $\phi(z)$:
$$
\phi(-\alpha + u) = \phi(0) e^{-\alpha u + \frac{1}{2}u^2} \sim \phi(0) \left(1 - \alpha u + \frac{1}{2}u^2 + \cdots \right) e^{\frac{1}{2}u^2}.
$$
Focusing on the $u^{-1}$-like contribution, we find:
$$
\int_0^\delta \frac{\phi(z)}{D} \, du \sim \frac{2\phi(0)}{D} \int_0^\delta e^{-\alpha u} \, du \quad \text{(after approximating the polynomial part)}.
$$
Actually, the **critical term** comes from:
$$
\int_0^\delta \frac{e^{-\alpha u}}{u} \, du = \int_{\alpha}^{\alpha \delta} \frac{e^{-v}}{v} \, dv = \log\left( \frac{1}{\alpha} \right) + \log\delta + \int_{\alpha \delta}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-v}}{v} dv + \text{const}.
$$
Using the identity:
$$
\int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-\alpha u} - 1}{u} e^{-u^2/2} du = -\log\alpha + \log\gamma + \psi(1) + o(1),
$$
we find that the constant term depends on $\gamma$. Here, $\psi(1) = -\gamma_E$, the Euler–Mascheroni constant.

**Inference:** The full asymptotic expansion of $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ is:
$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma} = \frac{2\phi(0)}{\sigma^2} \left[ \log\left( \frac{1}{\alpha} \right) + \log\gamma - \psi(1) + \frac{c_1}{\log(1/\alpha)} + o\left( \frac{1}{\log(1/\alpha)} \right) \right],
$$
where $c_1 = \psi(1) - \log\gamma$.

**Intermediate Conclusion:** The coefficient of $\log(1/\alpha)$ is $\boxed{\dfrac{2\phi(0)}{\sigma^2}} = \dfrac{2}{\sigma^2 \sqrt{2\pi}}$, which is **independent of $\gamma$**. The dependence on $\gamma$ enters only in the constant term $\log\gamma - \psi(1)$.

---

#### **Step 5: Primary vs. Alternative Hypotheses**

- **Primary Hypothesis:** The logarithmic divergence of $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ arises from a boundary-layer integral near $z = -\alpha$, where the truncated normal density transitions sharply to zero. The $1/u$ singularity in the integrand, due to the product of a linear polynomial and the $e^{-\alpha u}$ decay, generates the $\log(1/\alpha)$ term. The coefficient is determined by the **asymptotic matching** of the boundary-layer solution to the bulk.

- **Alternative Hypothesis:** One might suppose that the divergence comes from the **derivative of $\log D$** in the off-diagonal term. But $\partial_\mu \log D = \frac{\phi(\alpha)}{D} \cdot \frac{1}{\sigma}$, and $\partial_\sigma \log D = \frac{\alpha \phi(\alpha)}{D} \cdot \frac{1}{\sigma}$, so their product is $O(\alpha)$, which is negligible compared to $O(\log(1/\alpha))$. Thus, this term cannot produce the divergence. This confirms that the divergence is **purely due to the boundary-layer integral**, not the boundary derivative.

- **Another Alternative Hypothesis:** Could the divergence be due to the upper tail? But since $\beta = \gamma/\alpha \to \infty$, $\phi(\beta)$ is exponentially small, and the upper tail contributes only $O(e^{-\gamma^2/(2\alpha^2)})$, which is subdominant. Hence, only the lower tail matters.

---

### **Conclusion: Final Synthesis**

The Fisher information matrix in the degenerate limit $\alpha \to 0^+$, $\beta = \gamma/\alpha$, $\gamma > 0$ fixed, exhibits a logarithmic divergence in the off-diagonal element $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$, while the diagonal elements remain finite. The leading-order asymptotic expansion is:
$$
\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma} = \frac{2}{\sigma^2 \sqrt{2\pi}} \log\left( \frac{1}{\alpha} \right) + \frac{2}{\sigma^2 \sqrt{2\pi}} \left( \log\gamma + \gamma_E \right) + \frac{2}{\sigma^2 \sqrt{2\pi}} \frac{\psi(1) - \log\gamma}{\log(1/\alpha)} + o\!\left( \frac{1}{\log(1/\alpha)} \right).
$$

The key insight is that the logarithmic singularity arises from the **rescaling of the boundary layer** near $z = -\alpha$, where the truncated density $\phi(z)$ decays as $e^{-\alpha u}$, and the polynomial term $z^3 - z$ contributes a $u^{-1}$-like integral. The independence of the leading coefficient from $\gamma$ reflects the **local nature** of the boundary layer, while the dependence on $\gamma$ in the constant term reflects the **global scaling** of the upper tail.

---

**Primary Hypothesis · Alternative Hypotheses · Conclusion (and, if needed, 《Correction》)**  
- **Primary Hypothesis:** The logarithmic divergence in $\mathcal{I}_{\mu\sigma}$ originates from the boundary-layer integral near $z = -\alpha$, driven by the $1/u$ singularity in the score product after standardization.  
- **Alternative Hypotheses:** (1) The divergence arises from the derivative of the normalization constant $\log D$ — ruled out by order analysis. (2) The upper tail contributes significantly — ruled out due to exponential suppression.  
- **Conclusion:** The leading coefficient of $\log(1/\alpha)$ is $\boxed{\dfrac{2}{\sigma^2 \sqrt{2\pi}}}$, independent of $\gamma$. The first three terms in the expansion are fully determined, with the constant term involving $\log\gamma$ and $\psi(1)$.  
― End ―

  $$
  \|\mathcal{L}\| = \sup_{f \ne 0} \frac{\| \mathcal{L} f \|_{\mathcal{Q}}}{\|f\|_{\mathcal{Q}}}
  $$
  where $\|f\|_{\mathcal{Q}} = \sum_{|\alpha| \leq k} 2^{-|\alpha|} \frac{p_\alpha(f)}{1 + p_\alpha(f)}$ (standard metric). But this is **not equivalent** to a single norm.

  $$
  \|\mathcal{L}^m\| \leq M^m.
  $$

  $$

  $$

**Conclusion**  
A separating Cournot equilibrium in which firm 1 adopts the high‑efficiency technology \(H\) (paying the subsidised fixed cost \(\alpha F\)) and firm 2 stays with the low‑efficiency technology \(L\) exists iff the parameters satisfy  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&c-\delta \;\le\; a \;\le\; c+2\delta , \qquad (\text{positive outputs and firm 2’s IC})\\[4pt]
&4\delta\bigl[(a-c)+\delta\bigr]\;\ge\; 9\alpha F , \qquad (\text{firm 1’s IC})\\[4pt]
&a>c . \qquad (\text{demand positive})
\end{aligned}}
\tag{1}
\]

In a continuous‑time setting with irreversible adoption and a Poisson obsolescence hazard \(\lambda\) (discount rate \(r\)), the same conditions hold after inflating the fixed‑cost term by the factor \(1+\lambda/r\):

\[
4\delta\bigl[(a-c)+\delta\bigr]\;\ge\; 9\alpha F\!\left(1+\frac{\lambda}{r}\right) .
\tag{2}
\]

When (1) (or (2) in the dynamic model) holds with a **strict** inequality, the equilibrium is locally robust: a small change \(\Delta\alpha\) leaves the sign of  

\[
\Phi(\alpha)=4\delta[(a-c)+\delta]-9\alpha F
\]

unchanged, so firm 1 continues to prefer \(H\) and firm 2 continues to prefer \(L\). Near the knife‑edge \(\Phi(\alpha)=0\) the equilibrium becomes fragile—any infinitesimal increase in \(\alpha\) eliminates the separation.

1. **Cournot quantities** for marginal costs \(c_i,c_j\) under linear demand \(P(Q)=a-Q\):  

\[
q_i^{*}=\frac{a-2c_i+c_j}{3},\qquad 
q_j^{*}=\frac{a-2c_j+c_i}{3},
\]

requiring \(a-2c_i+c_j\ge0\) and \(a-2c_j+c_i\ge0\).

2. **Static profits** (per period) in the four technology profiles:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\pi_1^{(H,L)} &=\frac{(a-c+2\delta)^2}{9}-\alpha F,\\
\pi_2^{(L,H)} &=\frac{(a-c-\delta)^2}{9}-F,\\
\pi_1^{(L,L)} &=\pi_2^{(L,L)} =\frac{(a-c)^2}{9},\\
\pi_2^{(H,H)} &=\frac{(a-c+2\delta)^2}{9}-F .
\end{aligned}
\]

3. **Incentive‑compatibility** for the separating profile \((H,L)\):

* Firm 1: \(\pi_1^{(H,L)}\ge \pi_1^{(L,L)}\) ⇒  
\[
4\delta[(a-c)+\delta]\ge 9\alpha F .

\[

\]

which simplifies to (2). Thus a higher \(\lambda\) (faster obsolescence) tightens the required subsidy or efficiency gain, but the qualitative pattern of separation remains the same.

### **Introduction: Problem Framing and Strategic Context**

This analysis investigates the conditions under which a **separating equilibrium** emerges in a duopoly where two asymmetric firms sequentially choose between adopting a high-efficiency, high-fixed-cost technology (H) or a low-efficiency, low-cost technology (L). The key asymmetry lies in firm 1’s access to a subsidized R&D program, reducing its effective fixed cost to $ \alpha F $ ($ 0 < \alpha < 1 $), while firm 2 bears the full cost $ F $. The strategic environment is governed by **Cournot competition**, with technology adoption occurring prior to output decisions and being irreversible. The core question is: *Under what parameter configurations does a unique, stable equilibrium arise in which only firm 1 adopts H, and firm 2 optimally stays with L?*

The analysis proceeds through a **multi-layered reasoning process**:
- First, we derive the **static Cournot equilibrium** for all four technology combinations.
- Then, we formulate **incentive-compatibility (IC) constraints** that define a separating equilibrium.
- Next, we examine the **robustness** of this equilibrium to small changes in the subsidy intensity $ \alpha $.
- Finally, we extend the model to a **continuous-time dynamic setting**, incorporating **irreversible adoption** and **Poisson-driven technological obsolescence** with rate $ \lambda $.

---

### **Step 1: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
#### *Premise:* Linear inverse demand $ P(Q) = a - Q $, constant marginal costs, and symmetric Cournot best responses.

#### *Inference:*  
Given constant marginal costs $ c_i $ and $ c_j $, the Cournot reaction functions are linear and symmetric:
$$
q_i = \frac{a - c_i - q_j}{2}, \quad q_j = \frac{a - c_j - q_i}{2}.
$$
Solving simultaneously yields:
$$
q_i^* = \frac{a - 2c_i + c_j}{3}, \quad q_j^* = \frac{a - 2c_j + c_i}{3}.
$$
These quantities are **feasible only if non-negative**, implying:
$$
a - 2c_i + c_j \ge 0, \quad a - 2c_j + c_i \ge 0.
$$
This sets **minimum demand thresholds** for positive output.

#### *Intermediate Conclusion:*  
Closed-form expressions for equilibrium outputs are available. The structure depends on relative marginal costs. The high-efficiency technology $ H $ reduces marginal cost from $ c $ to $ c - \delta $, $ \delta > 0 $. This shift alters both output and profit dynamics in a predictable way.

---

### **Step 2: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
#### *Premise:* Profits depend on Cournot outputs and fixed costs tied to technology adoption.

#### *Inference:*  
Using the standard Cournot profit formula:
$$
\pi_i = (P - c_i) q_i - \mathbf{1}_{\{\text{adopt } H\}} F_i,
$$
and substituting the equilibrium quantities, we obtain:
$$
\pi_i^{(x,y)} = \frac{(a - 2c_i + c_j)^2}{9} - \mathbf{1}_{\{x=H\}} \alpha_i F,
$$
where $ \alpha_1 = \alpha $, $ \alpha_2 = 1 $. Substituting specific marginal costs:

- $ \pi_1^{(H,L)} = \frac{(a - c + 2\delta)^2}{9} - \alpha F $
- $ \pi_2^{(L,H)} = \frac{(a - c - \delta)^2}{9} - F $
- $ \pi_1^{(L,L)} = \pi_2^{(L,L)} = \frac{(a - c)^2}{9} $
- $ \pi_2^{(H,H)} = \frac{(a - c + 2\delta)^2}{9} - F $

Note: $ \pi_2^{(L,H)} $ is derived from firm 2’s marginal cost $ c $, firm 1’s $ c - \delta $. The asymmetry in $ \pi_2^{(L,H)} $ vs. $ \pi_2^{(H,H)} $ will be critical for IC2.

#### *Intermediate Conclusion:*  
Profit expressions are now fully specified. The **net gain from adopting $ H $** depends not only on marginal cost reduction but also on fixed cost burden and the opponent’s choice.

$$

$$

$$
\frac{(a - c + 2\delta)^2}{r + \lambda} - \frac{(a - c)^2}{r} \ge 9\alpha F
$$

- $ 4\delta[(a - c) + \delta] \ge 9\alpha F $: ensures firm 1’s net efficiency gain exceeds subsidized fixed cost.
- $ a > c $: prevents zero output.

However, this would only be credible if firm 1 could **signal** $ a $, which it cannot in this model. Since $ a $ is common knowledge, **no signaling is needed**, and AH1 fails.

#### **Alternative Hypothesis 2 (AH2):**  
In a dynamic model, **firm 1 might delay adoption** to wait for a better technology, even if $ H $ is available now. But the model assumes **irreversible adoption** and **no learning about future tech**. Thus, delay would only reduce expected surplus. No—because firm 2’s adoption of $ H $ is **not credible** if $ a > c + 2\delta $, as shown by IC2. Thus, firm 1 cannot expect firm 2 to adopt $ H $, so free-riding is not viable.

The separating equilibrium is **sustainable only under a narrow, well-defined parameter regime**:
- Market size $ a $ must be **moderate**: not too large (else firm 2 adopts $ H $), not too small (else no output).
- Efficiency gain $ \delta $ must be **sufficiently large** relative to fixed cost $ F $ and subsidy $ \alpha $.
- The **subsidy $ \alpha $** must be low enough to make $ \alpha F $ a manageable burden.

In the **dynamic setting**, the equilibrium becomes **more fragile** due to the factor $ 1 + \lambda/r $. Faster obsolescence ($ \lambda \uparrow $) or higher discounting ($ r \downarrow $) increases the cost of waiting, but also shortens the benefit horizon—**the net effect is a tighter requirement** for separation.

Crucially, **separation is not automatic**: it relies on the **precise calibration** of $ a, \delta, F, \alpha $. The equilibrium is **locally robust** (small $ \alpha $-changes don’t break it), but **globally fragile**—a small increase in $ \alpha $ or decrease in $ \delta $ can collapse it.

---

**Primary Hypothesis · Alternative Hypotheses · Conclusion (and, if needed, 《Correction》)**  
Primary Hypothesis: A separating equilibrium $ (H,L) $ exists iff $ c - \delta \le a \le c + 2\delta $ and $ 4\delta[(a - c) + \delta] \ge 9\alpha F $.

# Think

## Introduction: Problem Context and Core Challenges

The problem centers on the existence, uniqueness, and asymptotic bias of the Maximum Likelihood Estimator (MLE) for a multivariate normal distribution $\mathbf{X} \sim \mathcal{N}_n(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})$ observed only within a non-convex truncation region $\mathcal{T} = \{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^n : \mathbf{A}\mathbf{x} \geq \mathbf{b}\}$, where $\mathbf{A} \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}$ has full row rank ($\operatorname{rank}(\mathbf{A}) = m$) but the constraints are not independent across dimensions. The truncation induces a complex dependency structure due to the interplay between linear inequalities and the covariance matrix $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$, leading to a non-convex support $\mathcal{T}$, which undermines standard regularity assumptions used in MLE theory.

The likelihood is defined as:
$$
\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}; \mathbf{X}_1, \dots, \mathbf{X}_N) = \prod_{i=1}^N \left[ \frac{\phi_n(\mathbf{X}_i; \boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})}{\Phi_m(\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\mu} + \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{A}^{\top} \mathbf{c}; \mathbf{b})} \right] \cdot \mathbb{I}_{\mathcal{T}}(\mathbf{X}_i),
$$
where $\mathbf{c}$ represents unknown Lagrange multipliers from a constrained optimization framework. This formulation implies that the normalization constant involves a multivariate normal CDF $\Phi_m(\cdot)$ evaluated at a linear transformation of the mean and covariance, which depends on the truncation geometry.

Key challenges arise from:
1. **Non-convexity of $\mathcal{T}$**: This can result in multiple connected components, non-smooth boundaries, and failure of standard concavity arguments.
2. **Singularity of Fisher information at boundary**: While nonsingular in the interior, $\mathbf{I}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ degenerates as $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) \to \partial\mathcal{M}$, invalidating classical asymptotic approximations.
3. **Lack of global concavity**: The Hessian of the log-likelihood is not globally positive definite, precluding direct use of convex optimization techniques.
4. **Closed-form bias derivation**: Requires high-order expansions and expressions for truncated moments involving matrix argument hypergeometric functions.

We address these through a structured integration of **asymptotic M-estimation theory**, **information geometry**, and **special function analysis**.

---

## Main Discussion: Step-by-Step Reasoning

### Step 1 – Population Criterion and Uniform Convergence

We define the expected log-likelihood (population criterion):
$$
\ell_0(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) = \mathbb{E}_0\left[\log \phi_n(\mathbf{X}; \boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) - \log \Phi_m(\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\mu} + \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{A}^{\top} \mathbf{c}; \mathbf{b})\right],
$$
where the expectation is under the true truncated distribution, i.e., conditional on $\mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{T}$. The term $\log \Phi_m(\cdot)$ appears as a deterministic penalty because it does not depend on the data realization $\mathbf{X}_i$, only on the parameters.

**Premise → Inference**: By assumption, the true parameters $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$ lie in the interior of $\mathcal{M}$, implying that $\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{X} \mid \mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{T}]$ and $\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^\top \mid \mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{T}]$ exist and are finite. Thus, the class of log-densities $\{\log \phi_n(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})\}$ is uniformly integrable over compact subsets of $\mathcal{M}$.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The Glivenko–Cantelli property holds for the empirical log-likelihood:  
$$
\sup_{(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) \in \Theta} \left| \ell_N(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) - \ell_0(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}) \right| \xrightarrow{a.s.} 0,
$$
for any compact $\Theta \subset \mathcal{M}$, due to the boundedness of the log-density and the finiteness of moments.

---

### Step 2 – Uniqueness via Strict Concavity of the Limiting Criterion

We examine the first- and second-order behavior of $\ell_0$. The population score at $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$ is:
$$
\mathbf{s}_0(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) = \mathbb{E}_0\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\mu},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} \log \phi_n(\mathbf{X}; \boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)\right] - \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\mu},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} \log \Phi_m(\cdot) = \mathbf{0},
$$
since the first term vanishes (by standard properties of the normal log-likelihood) and the second term has zero gradient at the true parameters (as $\Phi_m(\cdot)$ depends only on $\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}$, not on $\mathbf{X}$).

The Hessian of $\ell_0$ at $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$ is:
$$
\nabla^2_{\boldsymbol{\mu},\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} \ell_0(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) = -\mathbf{I}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0),
$$
which is negative definite by assumption (Condition 8). Hence, $\ell_0$ is **strictly concave** in a neighborhood of $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$.

**Premise → Inference**: Strict concavity of $\ell_0$ on a convex domain implies that the stationary point $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$ is the **unique global maximizer** of $\ell_0$ over $\mathcal{M}$.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The limiting objective is strictly concave and uniquely maximized at the true parameter, satisfying a key requirement for consistency.

---

### Step 3 – Existence and Uniqueness of MLE via Wald’s Theorem

Wald’s consistency theorem applies to M-estimators when:
- The empirical criterion converges uniformly to a limiting criterion (established in Step 1),
- The limiting criterion has a unique maximizer (established in Step 2),
- The parameter space is locally compact and identifiability holds.

Given:
- Identifiability (assumption 2): Different $(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})$ induce distinct conditional laws on $\mathcal{T}$,
- $\mathcal{M}$ is open in the parameter space (since $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) \in \operatorname{int}(\mathcal{M})$),
- Uniform convergence and strict concavity are verified,

We conclude:

(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) \xrightarrow{a.s.} (\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0),
$$
and for sufficiently large $N$, the argmax is **almost surely unique** because the empirical log-likelihood inherits strict concavity in a shrinking neighborhood around the true parameter (due to uniform convergence of the Hessian to $-\mathbf{I}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0)$, which is negative definite).

We now compile the logical conditions that **must** hold for the MLE to exist and be unique almost surely in the limit $N \to \infty$. These are derived from the above reasoning and verified against boundary degeneracies.

| Condition | Justification |
|--------|-------------|
| 1. **Identifiability** | Without it, multiple parameter pairs yield the same conditional distribution, making the MLE non-unique even in expectation. |
| 2. **Interior true parameters** | If $(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) \in \partial\mathcal{M}$, then $\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{X} \mid \mathbf{X} \in \mathcal{T}]$ may diverge, violating moment existence. |
| 3. **Finite conditional moments** | Required for the existence of $\ell_0$ and its derivatives; ensures no blow-up in score or information matrix. |
| 4. **Full row rank of $\mathbf{A}$** | Guarantees that $\mathcal{T}$ has non-zero probability under $\mathcal{N}_n(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)$, preventing degenerate likelihood. |
| 5. **Positive definiteness of Fisher information at interior** | Ensures strict concavity of $\ell_0$, which is essential for uniqueness. |

**Hypothesis**: If any of these five conditions fail, the MLE either fails to exist (e.g., likelihood unbounded) or is not unique (e.g., multiple maximizers due to flatness or symmetry).

**Alternative Hypothesis**: Non-convexity of $\mathcal{T}$ could induce multiple local modes even under strict concavity of $\ell_0$, if $\mathcal{T}$ has disconnected components. However, this is ruled out because:

### Step 5 – Asymptotic Bias via Higher-Order Expansion

We now derive the **leading-order asymptotic bias** of $(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}})$ using higher-order asymptotics. The MLE satisfies the estimating equation:
$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \mathbf{s}(\mathbf{X}_i; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) = \mathbf{0},
$$
where $\mathbf{s} = \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \log f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\mathbf{X})$, and $\boldsymbol{\theta} = (\operatorname{vech}(\boldsymbol{\Sigma})^\top, \boldsymbol{\mu}^\top)^\top$.

Expanding $\mathbf{s}(\mathbf{X}; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})$ in Taylor series around $\boldsymbol{\theta}_0$:
$$
\mathbf{0} = \mathbf{s}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) + \mathbf{H}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} - \boldsymbol{\theta}_0) + \frac{1}{2} \sum_{j,k} \mathbf{T}_{jk} (\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_j - \theta_{0j})(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_k - \theta_{0k}) + \cdots
$$
Taking expectations and solving yields:
$$
\mathbb{E}[\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}} - \boldsymbol{\theta}_0] = \mathbf{I}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) \left[ \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{tr}\left( \mathbf{I}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) \mathbf{K}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) \right) - \mathbf{J}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) \right] + o(N^{-1}),

where:
- $\mathbf{K}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_0) = \mathbb{E}_0[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{s}(\mathbf{X}; \boldsymbol{\theta}_0) \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{s}(\mathbf{X}; \boldsymbol{\theta}_0)^\top]$,

The key insight is that **truncated moments of the multivariate normal** under linear inequality constraints admit closed-form representations via generalized hypergeometric functions of matrix arguments. Specifically:

Let $\mathbf{Z} = \mathbf{A}\mathbf{X} \sim \mathcal{N}_m(\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\mu}, \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{A}^\top)$. Then the normalization constant is:

\Phi_m(\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\mu} + \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\mathbf{A}^\top \mathbf{c}; \mathbf{b}) = \mathbb{P}(\mathbf{Z} \geq \mathbf{b}).
$$

$$
\mathbf{M} = \frac{{}_2F_1\left(\frac{1}{2}, 1; \frac{m+4}{2}; \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \mathbf{A}^\top\right)}{{}_0F_1\left(\frac{m}{2}; \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \mathbf{A}^\top\right)} \cdot \mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \mathbf{A}^\top.

$$

\operatorname{Bias}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}) &= \frac{1}{N} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0^{-1} \left[ \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \mathbf{A}^\top \left( \mathbf{M} - \frac{1}{2} \mathbf{I}_m \right) \mathbf{A} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \right] \Delta + o(N^{-1}), \\

$$

---

The analysis reveals that the MLE for a non-convexly truncated multivariate normal model enjoys strong asymptotic properties **if and only if** the five regularity conditions hold. The non-convexity of the truncation set does not obstruct existence or uniqueness provided the interiority and moment conditions are met.

The leading-order bias is **exactly characterized** by matrix hypergeometric functions arising from the structure of truncated moments. - **Inference**: In the PBE, the allocation rule is **deterministic but misaligned**: $T_H$ goes to any firm whose type is low *and* whose signal (via $t_A$) triggers a favorable belief.   $$

  $$

  $$

  $$

Under these conditions, strategic misallocation arises when the fixed-cost disadvantage of $T_H$ exceeds the discounted expected marginal-cost advantage, leading to an inefficient allocation where the less capable firm adopts $T_H$ due to signal jamming. This misallocation causes a strictly positive welfare loss.
- **Alternative Hypotheses**:
  - *Pooling Equilibrium*: Could exist if $\Delta F$ is extremely large, but it fails to satisfy the separating requirement and cannot generate misallocation via signaling.
  - *Reverse Misallocation*: If $\delta_L > \delta_H$, $T_H$ becomes less risky, reducing the incentive for misallocation. But the model assumes $\delta_H > \delta_L$, so this is ruled out.
  - *Welfare Improvement via Misallocation?*: Only in highly non-standard settings (e.g., network effects or learning-by-doing), but these are absent here.
- **Conclusion**: The separating PBE is efficient in terms of incentive compatibility and belief consistency but inefficient in terms of social welfare due to information-based distortion. The welfare loss is not due to risk or uncertainty per se, but due to **incentives to misrepresent capability via technology choice**.

― End ―

### 1. Master equation for the graph ensemble  

Let \(\mathcal R\) be the set of stochastic graph‑grammar productions \(\rho\).  
For a rule \(\rho\) applied at spatial location \(\mathbf x\) the instantaneous propensity is  

\[
a_\rho(\mathcal G,\mathbf x,t)=\lambda\,f_\rho(\mathcal G)\bigl[1+\eta\,\xi(\mathbf x,t)\bigr]\,

\]

with \(\lambda\) the base rate, \(f_\rho\) the combinatorial factor, \(\eta\) the noise coupling, \(\xi\) a fractional Gaussian field (covariance \(\langle\xi(\mathbf x,t)\xi(\mathbf x',t')\rangle=\xi_0^{2}\|\mathbf x-\mathbf x'\|^{2H-d}\delta(t-t')\)), and \(\mathcal K(\tau)\sim \tau^{-\alpha}\) (\(0<\alpha<1\)) the memory kernel governing edge‑weight dynamics.

\tag{1}
\]

\[
\tilde a_\rho(\mathcal G,\mathbf x,t)=\lambda f_\rho(\mathcal G)\bigl[1+\eta\,\xi(\mathbf x,t)\bigr]
\ast \mathcal{M}(t),\qquad 
\mathcal{M}(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}\!\Bigl[\frac{1}{1+s^{\alpha}\tau^{\alpha}}\Bigr],

\gamma = 1+\frac{1}{\beta}+C\,\eta^{2}\,\ell^{2H},

\gamma(L)=\gamma_0-\frac{A\,\xi_0^{2}}{2H-d}\Bigl(L^{2H-d}-\ell_0^{2H-d}\Bigr).

### **Main Discussion**

#### **Step 1: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise**: The genome is represented as a directed, weighted graph $ \mathcal{G} = (V, E, w) $, where nodes are regulatory modules and edges denote functional interactions with time-varying strength $ w_{ij}(t) $. Rewiring occurs via stochastic graph-grammar productions $ \rho \in \mathcal{R} $, each with a spatially modulated rate.

**Inference**: The evolution of $ P(\mathcal{G}, t) $ must account for both discrete graph transformations (via SGG) and continuous edge dynamics (via Langevin equation with memory). Since edge weights are governed by a non-Markovian kernel $ \mathcal{K}(t-s) \sim (t-s)^{-\alpha} $ ($ 0 < \alpha < 1 $), the system requires an auxiliary history variable to encode past weight values. This leads to a *functional master equation* over the joint space of graph configurations and weight histories.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The full evolution equation is:
$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} P(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{w}, t) = \sum_{\rho} \int_\Omega d\mathbf{x} \left[ a_\rho(\mathcal{G}^-_\rho, \mathbf{x}, t) P(\mathcal{G}^-_\rho, \mathbf{w}, t) - a_\rho(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{x}, t) P(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{w}, t) \right] + \mathcal{L}_{\text{mem}}[P],
$$
where $ \mathcal{L}_{\text{mem}} $ governs the memory-driven edge dynamics:
$$
\mathcal{L}_{\text{mem}}[P] = \sum_{i,j} \frac{\partial}{\partial w_{ij}} \left[ \int_0^t \mathcal{K}(t-s) w_{ij}(s)\,ds \cdot P - D \frac{\partial P}{\partial w_{ij}} \right].
$$
This establishes the **exact master equation**, capturing both stochastic rewiring and epigenetic memory.

---

#### **Step 2: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise**: The edge-weight dynamics are linear and Gaussian, allowing for analytical marginalization over $ \mathbf{w} $. The effective rewiring rate $ \tilde{a}_\rho $ incorporates the average influence of the memory kernel.

**Inference**: In the Laplace domain, the memory kernel $ \mathcal{K}(t) \sim t^{-\alpha} $ transforms to $ \mathcal{K}(s) \sim s^{\alpha-1} $, so the effective rate becomes:
$$
\tilde{a}_\rho(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{x}, s) = \lambda f_\rho(\mathcal{G}) \left[1 + \eta \xi(\mathbf{x}, s)\right] \cdot \frac{1}{1 + s^\alpha \tau^\alpha}.
$$
Inverting this yields a time-convolved rate:
$$
\tilde{a}_\rho(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{x}, t) = \lambda f_\rho(\mathcal{G}) \left[1 + \eta \xi(\mathbf{x}, t)\right] * \mathcal{M}(t), \quad \mathcal{M}(t) = \mathcal{L}^{-1}\left[\frac{1}{1 + s^\alpha \tau^\alpha}\right].
$$
The kernel $ \mathcal{M}(t) $ is a stretched exponential or Mittag-Leffler function, implying **sub-diffusive rewiring**—a hallmark of long-memory processes.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The master equation reduces to a *graph-only* form:
$$
\boxed{
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} P(\mathcal{G}, t) = \sum_{\rho} \int_\Omega d\mathbf{x} \left[ \tilde{a}_\rho(\mathcal{G}^-_\rho, \mathbf{x}, t) P(\mathcal{G}^-_\rho, t) - \tilde{a}_\rho(\mathcal{G}, \mathbf{x}, t) P(\mathcal{G}, t) \right],
}
$$
where the rate $ \tilde{a}_\rho $ is slowed by epigenetic memory and modulated by spatial noise.

---

#### **Step 3: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise**: Rewiring follows a preferential attachment mechanism with degree exponent $ \beta $, but is modulated by a fractional Gaussian field $ \xi(\mathbf{x}, t) $ with Hurst exponent $ H $. This introduces spatial correlation in attachment bias.

**Inference**: The effective attachment probability becomes:
$$
\Pi(k_i, \mathbf{x}) \propto k_i^\beta \left[1 + \eta \xi(\mathbf{x}, t)\right].
$$
Since $ \xi $ is a FGF, its variance over a region of size $ \ell $ scales as $ \text{Var}[\xi] \sim \ell^{2H} $. This induces a scale-dependent bias: nodes in regions with high $ \xi $-amplitude attract more connections.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The stationary degree distribution remains power-law, but the exponent $ \gamma $ is shifted:
$$
\gamma = 1 + \frac{1}{\beta} + C \eta^2 \ell^{2H},
$$
where $ \ell $ is a coarse-graining length. Larger $ H $ (more persistent noise) or stronger $ \eta $ **reduces $ \gamma $**, favoring hubs and increasing network connectivity.

---

#### **Step 4: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise**: A phase transition from localized to global information propagation occurs when the graph Laplacian eigenvectors delocalize. For scale-free networks, eigenvector localization is governed by the eigenvalue density $ \rho(\lambda) \sim \lambda^{(\gamma - 3)/2} $ near $ \lambda = 0 $. Delocalization occurs when $ (\gamma - 3)/2 \geq 0 $, i.e., $ \gamma \geq 3 $.

**Inference**: The spatial noise field alters the effective dimensionality of the genomic embedding space via renormalization group (RG) scaling. Coarse-graining over scale $ \ell $ rescales noise amplitude as $ \xi_0 \to \xi_0 \ell^{H - d/2} $. The RG flow for $ \gamma $ is:
$$
\frac{d\gamma}{d\ln \ell} = -A \xi_0^2 \ell^{2H - d},
$$
with $ A > 0 $. Integrating from microscopic cutoff $ \ell_0 $ to system size $ L $ (e.g., nuclear diameter):
$$
\gamma(L) = \gamma_0 - \frac{A \xi_0^2}{2H - d} \left( L^{2H - d} - \ell_0^{2H - d} \right).
$$
Setting $ \gamma(L) = 3 $ gives the **critical exponent**:
$$
\boxed{
\gamma_c(H, d, \xi_0) = \gamma_0 - \frac{A \xi_0^2}{2H - d} \left( L^{2H - d} - \ell_0^{2H - d} \right).
}
$$
This reveals that:
- Higher $ H $ (longer-range noise correlations) **lowers $ \gamma_c $**, promoting global propagation.
- Larger $ \xi_0 $ (stronger epigenetic noise) **lowers $ \gamma_c $**.
- When $ 2H - d > 0 $, the correction grows with system size; when $ 2H - d < 0 $, it decays.

**Alternative Hypothesis**: If the graph-grammar includes *anti-preferential* rules (e.g., hubs are deleted), $ \gamma $ may not follow the above form. In such cases, $ \gamma_c $ could be *increased* due to network fragmentation, requiring a modified RG flow with sink terms.

---

#### **Step 5: Premise → Inference → Intermediate Conclusion**  
**Premise**: Single-cell multi-omics time-series data (ATAC-seq, ChIP-seq, scRNA-seq) provide noisy, sparse observations of regulatory module activity and spatial coordinates.

**Inference**: A data-driven pipeline must reconstruct the graph, estimate $ \gamma(t) $, infer $ H $ and $ \xi_0 $, and detect the crossover time $ t^* $ when information propagation shifts globally.

**Intermediate Conclusion**: The inference algorithm is structured as follows:

| Step | Action | Key Insight |
|------|--------|-----------|
| 1 | **Graph reconstruction** | Construct sparse, cell-specific adjacency matrices using FDR-controlled thresholding of co-accessibility or co-modification. |
| 2 | **Degree exponent estimation** | Fit power-law tails of $ P(k) $ using maximum-likelihood (e.g., Clauset et al. 2009). Obtain $ \gamma^{(c)}(t) $. |

| 5 | **Critical exponent inference** | Use $ \gamma_c \approx \langle \gamma^{(c)}(t^*) \rangle $ and regress against $ H $, $ \xi_0 $, $ d $ using $ \gamma_c = \alpha_0 - \alpha_1 \xi_0^2 / (2H - d) $. |
| 6 | **Validation** | Simulate SGG dynamics with inferred parameters; verify IPR crossover matches data. |

This pipeline enables **causal inference** of $ \gamma_c $ from experimental data, linking epigenetic noise to network criticality.

---

### **Creative Insight and Counterargument Consideration**

- **New Insight**: The critical exponent $ \gamma_c $ is not a fixed constant but a **dynamical threshold** modulated by *epigenetic noise coherence* (via $ H $) and *spatial scale* (via $ L $). This reframes the phase transition as a **noise-driven criticality**—a hallmark of biological systems under stress.

- **Counterargument**: Could the observed IPR crossover be due to technical artifacts (e.g., batch effects, low coverage)?  
  **Response**: The bootstrap validation and synthetic simulation steps mitigate this—only reproducible, statistically robust transitions are accepted.

- **Alternative Hypothesis**: What if the system exhibits *fractal* topology (e.g., $ d_{\text{fractal}} \neq d $)? Then $ H $ and $ d $ must be replaced by effective fractal dimension $ d_f $. This leads to:
  $$

  $$
  This generalizes the result to non-integer embeddings.

### **Conclusion**

The formal framework unifies stochastic graph grammars, non-Markovian memory, and spatially correlated epigenetic noise into a coherent model of pseudotribos genome dynamics. The master equation captures the full stochastic evolution, while the RG-based derivation of $ \gamma_c $ reveals how epigenetic noise dictates the critical topology for global information flow. The algorithm enables experimental validation, turning theoretical predictions into testable hypotheses.

2. **Assessing evolutionary fate of coding-region SVs**: Fixation probability under strong purifying selection ($s = -0.03$) in a finite population ($N_e = 10^4$).

  $$

  $$

- **Intermediate Conclusion**: The mean number of SVs is robustly estimated under the Poisson assumption, valid due to low $\lambda$ and large $G_d$, ensuring rare-event independence.

> **Note**: While SVs have a mean length of 1.5 kb and follow a normal-like distribution with $\sigma = 0.6$ kb, **length does not affect the count of SVs**, only their genomic footprint. - **Premise**: 18% of the genome is functional (coding/non-coding functional elements), but **72% of SVs fall within functional regions**, indicating **non-uniform targeting** or **biased insertion**.

  $$

  $$

  $$

  $$
  u_{\text{fix}} \approx \frac{1 - e^{0.06}}{1 - e^{1200}} \approx \frac{-0.0618}{-e^{1200}} = 0.0618 \cdot e^{-1200}.
  $$

A symmetric Bayesian Nash equilibrium (BNE) in which both firms adopt the low‑cost, high‑variability technology (LHV) exists **iff**

\[
\boxed{\;\kappa+\sigma^{2}\;\ge\;\bigl(a-c_{H}-b\bar c\bigr)^{2}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

where  

* \(\bar c=\dfrac{c_{\min}+c_{\max}}{2}\) is the mean of the uniform baseline‑cost distribution,  
* \(\displaystyle\kappa=\frac{1}{3\,(c_{\max}-c_{\min})}\Bigl[(a-b\bar c-c_{\min})^{3}-(a-b\bar c-c_{\max})^{3}\Bigr]\) captures the profit effect of cost heterogeneity, and  
* \(\sigma^{2}\) is the variance of the LHV cost shock \(\epsilon\).

When (1) holds, each firm’s optimal quantity as a function of its **realized** marginal cost \(\tilde c_i=c_i+\epsilon_i\) is

\[
\boxed{\;q_i^{*}(\tilde c_i)=\frac{a-\tilde c_i-b\bar c}{3b}\;},\qquad 
\tilde c_i\in\mathbb R .
\tag{2}
\]

The equilibrium profit of a firm that chose LHV is  

\[
\pi_i^{L}= \frac{\bigl(a-\tilde c_i-b\bar c\bigr)^{2}}{9b},
\]

and its **expected** profit is  

\[
\mathbb E[\pi_i^{L}] = \frac{\kappa+\sigma^{2}}{9b}.
\]

A unilateral deviation to the high‑cost, low‑variability technology (HLV) yields expected profit  

\[
\mathbb E[\pi_i^{H}] = \frac{\bigl(a-c_{H}-b\bar c\bigr)^{2}}{9b},
\]

so (1) is precisely the no‑deviation condition.

---

### Welfare implications  

*Total expected welfare* (consumer surplus + producer surplus) under the LHV‑only equilibrium is  

\[
W_{LHV}= \frac{b}{2}\, \bigl(2E[q^{*}]\bigr)^{2}
        + 2\,\mathbb E[\pi_i^{L}]
        =\frac{2}{9b}\bigl(\kappa+\sigma^{}\bigr)
          +\frac{2}{9b}\bigl(a-b\bar c-\bar c\bigr)^{2},
\]

where \(E[q^{*}]=\dfrac{a-b\bar c-\bar c}{3b}\) uses \(E[\tilde c]=\bar c\).

If a planner forces both firms to adopt HLV, welfare is  

\[
W_{HLV}= \frac{2}{9b}\bigl(a-c_{H}-b c_{H}\bigr)^{2}.
\]

Hence the socially optimal technology allocation coincides with the private equilibrium **iff** the same inequality (1) holds after replacing \(\bar c\) on the left‑hand side by the deterministic cost \(c_{H}\) on the right‑hand side. When (1) is satisfied, LHV maximizes total surplus; otherwise, the planner would prefer HLV for both firms.

---

### Effect of the “Kennedy effect’’ and opaque performance data  

The Kennedy effect is modeled as an **optimism bias** \(\Delta>0\) that makes a firm perceive its LHV cost as lower (or its variance as smaller) than it truly is when interpreting ambiguous audit information. Two mechanisms arise:

1. **Bias in expected cost** – the firm substitutes \(\tilde c_i^{\,\text{perceived}} = \tilde c_i - \Delta\). In (2) this raises the quantity it plans to produce, making LHV appear more profitable. The no‑deviation condition becomes  

   \[
   \kappa+\sigma^{2}+2\Delta\bigl(a-b\bar c-\bar c\bigr)+\Delta^{2}\;\ge\;(a-c_{H}-b\bar c)^{2},
   \]

   i.e. the left‑hand side is strictly larger, so the set of parameters for which LHV is an equilibrium expands.

2. **Opaque (“gum”) audit format** – ambiguous data increase the **interpretive noise** \(\nu\) that firms attach to the variance estimate, effectively replacing \(\sigma^{2}\) by \(\sigma^{2}+\nu^{2}\). This again enlarges the left‑hand side of (1), reinforcing the incentive to adopt LHV even when the true variance is modest.

Consequently, when the Kennedy effect and opaque information are present, firms are more likely to coordinate on the LHV technology, potentially leading to an equilibrium that **over‑adopts** a risky process relative to the socially optimal allocation. The welfare impact is ambiguous: consumer surplus may rise because of lower average prices, but the increased production risk can raise the probability of high marginal‑cost realizations, reducing expected producer surplus and possibly generating excess volatility in the market.

--- 

**Summary** – The existence of a symmetric LHV‑only BNE hinges on inequality (1); the equilibrium strategy is the linear mapping (2). Welfare comparison uses the same inequality with the rival’s cost replaced by the deterministic HLV cost. Psychological optimism (Kennedy effect) and opaque audit signals shift the perceived cost distribution in favor of LHV, expanding the equilibrium region and potentially creating a welfare mismatch between private incentives and the social optimum.
